title: Worley receives first strike after backlash on cash bonuses
text:
Worley has received a first strike on its remuneration report after giving $680,000 in special cash bonuses to top executives for completing a $4.6 billion takeover that has left the engineering group's shareholders worse off.

Some 30 per cent of votes cast at Worley's annual general meeting in Sydney on Thursday were against the engineering group's remuneration report, even though its biggest shareholder, Dubai-based Dar Group, abstained.

The so-called "strike" - which occurs when at least 25 per cent of votes are cast against a remuneration report - means Worley must address shareholder concerns to avoid a second strike next year. If it receives two consecutive strikes, it must hold a vote ­asking ­investors whether they want to spill the board.

Investors are unhappy with the payment of a $480,000 special cash bonus paid to chief executive Andrew Wood and a $200,000 cash to chief financial officer Tom Honan paid immediately after completing Worley's acquisition of Jacobs Engineering Group's energy, resources and chemicals business in April.

Worley's remuneration committee chairman, former Brambles CEO Tom Gorman, told the meeting that the special bonuses had been paid to recognise the "extraordinary effort and critical role" the two men had played in completing the Jacobs acquisition.

But the Australian Shareholders' Association (ASA), which urged investors to vote against the remuneration report, said Worley should justify the takeover through "performance rather than aspiration."
description: Investors are unhappy with bonuses paid to top executives after Worley's $4.6 billion takeover of Jacobs' energy business.
